topic.name: Systematic Reading of Scripture
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Systematic Reading of Scripture in Bible & Theology

objectives.objective_text: Identify the Bible as God's special book that should be opened every day.
Name specific times of the day (morning or night) when we can hear from God.
Identify the main person in the story.
Identify a verse that brings comfort when afraid.
Identify what a Bible story teaches us about God's love.
Identify the main character in a Bible story.
Identify one word or phrase that stands out.
Identify the very first book (Genesis) and the very last book (Revelation).
Name the four Gospels as the stories about Jesus.
Observe a parent or teacher reading the Bible and imitate the posture of listening.
Observe what is happening in a picture of a Bible story.
Listen quietly to a short Bible reading.
Recall that the Bible has two main parts: the Old Testament and the New Testament.
Describe what happens in a story using pictures or simple words.
Express a simple prayer back to God about the reading.
Retell what happened in the beginning, middle, and end.
Ask to hear stories from the Bible as part of a daily routine.
Explain why reading the Bible daily is food for the Christian soul.
Summarize the main thought of a short daily passage in a journal.
Explain the difference between reading for information and reading for transformation.
Defend the necessity of daily Scripture intake against the cultural pressure of busyness.
Ask 'Who?', 'What?', and 'Where?' questions about a story.
Summarize the three steps: Observation, Interpretation, Application.
Explain why we must look at what the text says before what it means.
Explain the danger of jumping to application without proper observation.
Perform independent research on historical background to aid observation.
Produce a teaching outline based on the inductive study of a passage.
Memorize short key verses (e.g., Genesis 1:1, John 3:16).
Repeat a verse out loud until it can be said without help.
Copy a memory verse in best handwriting.
Memorize longer passages or sets of verses (e.g., The Beatitudes, Psalm 23).
Explain the meaning of a memorized verse in own words.
Explain the Puritan concept of 'chewing' on the Word (meditation) for spiritual nourishment.
Research the context of a memory verse to ensure it is applied correctly.
Produce a written meditation on a passage, exploring its implications deeply.
Defend the discipline of 'hiding God's Word in the heart' as essential for spiritual warfare.
Ask, 'What does God want me to do?' after hearing a story.
Copy a short verse that helps us trust Jesus.
Express thanks to God for the truth found in His Word.
Explain how a passage encourages us to love God or love our neighbor.
Summarize what a text reveals about God's character (e.g., He is holy, He is kind).
Participate in a guided prayer based on a Psalm.
Explain how the Holy Spirit uses the Word to change our hearts.
Produce a devotional reflection that applies deep theological truth to daily life.
Defend the practice of reading for relationship over reading for mere academic knowledge.
Retell the main events of a Bible story in the correct order.
Ask questions about words or ideas in the Bible that are hard to understand.
Summarize the 'Who, What, When, Where' of a passage.
Explain the plain meaning of a text without adding to it.
Categorize a passage as a story, a song, or a rule/command.
Explain the difference between observation (what it says) and interpretation (what it means).
Perform independent word studies to clarify the meaning of crucial terms.
Produce a written summary of a passage that accurately reflects the author's intent.
Ask God to help understand the special word.
Summarize the four steps: Read, Think, Pray, Rest (Lectio, Meditatio, Oratio, Contemplatio).
Explain what it feels like to listen to God through His Word.
Participate in a guided time of quiet reading and prayer.
Explain how 'chewing' on the text (Meditatio) leads to prayer (Oratio).
Produce a journal entry documenting the movement from reading to contemplation.
Defend the historical validity of this practice within the Protestant tradition.
Follow along in a picture Bible as an adult reads through major stories.
Categorize Bible books into Law, History, Poetry, Prophecy, Gospels, and Letters.
Summarize the general flow of the Bible from Creation to the New Heavens.
Explain the value of reading the 'whole counsel of God' rather than just favorite verses.
Perform independent research to understand the historical setting of the books being read.
Produce a synthesis of a major theme traced through a whole-Bible reading.
Apply a simple checklist to track reading the Bible for a full week.
Compare the habit of Bible reading to other daily habits like brushing teeth or eating.
Analyze personal schedules to identify obstacles to consistent Bible reading.
Connect the practice of daily reading to the concept of 'abiding' in Christ (John 15).
Apply specific color codes to mark key words in a printed text.
Compare the characters in a story to understand their choices.
Analyze a paragraph by circling key words, listing facts, and noting contrasts.
Interpret the meaning of a passage based only on the observations made.
Connect the interpretation to a specific, actionable application.
Apply a memorized verse to a specific temptation or struggle.
Compare the difference between just knowing the words and thinking about them (meditation).
Analyze a memorized passage by breaking it down phrase by phrase.
Connect memorized verses to other parts of the Bible to support a doctrine.
Apply a specific command from Scripture to a situation at school or home.
Analyze own heart responses to Scripture (conviction, comfort, or confusion).
Connect the truths of a passage to personal struggles and doubts.
Interpret the difference between moralism (being good) and gospel fruit (loving Christ).
Compare two different stories to find similarities in how God acts.
Analyze a passage to determine the author's main point.
Interpret the meaning of key words within their immediate context.
Connect a specific passage to the broader context of the chapter.
Apply the method to a short Psalm.
Analyze how slowing down reading helps notice details often missed.
Interpret the difference between studying for facts and reading for communion.
Connect the historical practice of Lectio Divina to the modern quiet time.
Apply a reading plan to finish one entire book of the Bible.
Compare the length and style of different books (e.g., Psalms vs. Mark).
Analyze the structure of a canonical reading plan versus a chronological one.
Connect individual books to the larger metanarrative of Scripture.
Interpret how the Old Testament prepares the way for the New Testament.
Evaluate different times of day to determine when personal focus is highest for reading.
Evaluate the spiritual impact of inconsistency and develop strategies for discipline.
Evaluate different commentaries to check personal interpretation.
Evaluate the role of meditation in fighting sin and cultivating joy.
Evaluate personal life choices in light of specific Scriptural principles.
Evaluate a text to determine the author's logical flow and argument.
Evaluate the benefits of contemplative reading in a distracted digital age.
Evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of different reading plans (MCheyne, Chronological, etc.).
Construct a sustainable, long-term plan for reading through the entire Bible.
Synthesize daily reading habits with deep study to produce a holistic view of Scripture.
Construct a full inductive study of a New Testament epistle (Observation, Interpretation, Application).
Construct a system for retaining and reviewing memorized Scripture over time.
Construct a detailed outline of a biblical chapter or book.
Construct a personal rhythm of reading that incorporates silence and reflection.
Construct a personalized plan to read the entire Bible in one or two years.
Construct prayers that are saturated with the language and theology of the text read.
